instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Pp3v42 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL>  3.3v
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> 3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.4v 
Board looks pretty clean
Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.9k ohm, i have tried changing smc 3 times, but i donâ€™t know if its the smc or another problem..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Dc in board is known good
Does dead mcp can cause this ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Post all <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> voltages.
Did you check continuity from <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> to SMC and central pin of Magsafe?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6900</CHIP> pin 1 : 3.3v
4 : 3.3v
5 : 3.3v
Continuity on Pin 5 j6900 to <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> pin 5 is good
Continuity on <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> pin 5 to ball 96 of smc is good too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
"Continuity on Pin 5 j6900 to <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> pin 5 is good "
To the central pin of Magsafe, in the DCIN board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: continuity is good from <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> pin 5 to magsafe center on the dc in board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Try another charger, origi nal.
If still no light, bad SMC, or solders; if DCIN board is really good.

BTW, exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?
